cavejohnson.eighties_intro03.mp3: Since making test participation mandatory for all employees, the quality of our test subjects has risen dramatically. Employee retention, however, has not.
cavejohnson.eighties_intro04.mp3: [cough] As a result, you may have heard we're gonna phase out human testing. There's still a few things left to wrap up, though.
cavejohnson.eighties_intro07.mp3: The bean counters told me we literally could not afford to buy seven dollars worth of moon rocks, much less seventy million. Bought 'em anyway. Ground 'em up, mixed em into a gel.
cavejohnson.eighties_intro08.mp3: And guess what? Ground up moon rocks are pure poison. I am deathly ill.
cavejohnson.eighties_intro10.mp3: Still, it turns out they're a great portal conductor. So now we're gonna see if jumping in and out of these new portals can somehow leech the lunar poison out of a man's bloodstream. When life gives you lemons, make lemonade. [coughs] Let's all stay positive and do some science.
cavejohnson.eighties_intro12.mp3: That said, I would really appreciate it if you could test as fast as possible. Caroline, please bring me more pain pills.
cavejohnson.eighties_outro02.mp3: The point is: If we can store music on a compact disc, why can't we store a man's intelligence and personality on one? So I have the engineers figuring that out now.
cavejohnson.eighties_outro05.mp3: Brain Mapping. Artificial Intelligence. We should have been working on it thirty years ago. I will say this - and I'm gonna say it on tape so everybody hears it a hundred times a day: If I die before you people can pour me into a computer, I want Caroline to run this place.
cavejohnson.eighties_outro06.mp3: Now she'll argue. She'll say she can't. She's modest like that. But you make her.
cavejohnson.eighties_outro07.mp3: Hell, put her in my computer. I don't care.
cavejohnson.eighties_outro08.mp3: Allright, test's over. You can head on back to your desk.
cavejohnson.eighties_outro09.mp3: All right, I've been thinking. When life gives you lemons? Don't make lemonade. Make life take the lemons back! Get mad! 'I don't want your damn lemons! What am I supposed to do with these?'
cavejohnson.eighties_outro11.mp3: Demand to see life's manager! Make life rue the day it thought it could give Cave Johnson lemons! Do you know who I am? I'm the man who's going to burn your house down! With the lemons! I'm going to get my engineers to invent a combustible lemon that burns your house down!
cavejohnson.fifties_elevator_out_a01.mp3: They say great science is built on the shoulders of giants. Not here. At Aperture, we do all our science from scratch. No hand holding.
cavejohnson.fifties_fifth_test_complete03.mp3: Not you, test subject, you're doing fine.
cavejohnson.fifties_fifth_test_complete08.mp3: Yes, you. Box. Your stuff. Out the front door. Parking lot. Car. Goodbye.
cavejohnson.fifties_fifth_test_complete09.mp3: Science isn't about WHY. It's about WHY NOT. Why is so much of our science dangerous? Why not marry safe science if you love it so much. In fact, why not invent a special safety door that won't hit you on the butt on the way out, because you are fired.
cavejohnson.fifties_fifth_test_intro01.mp3: If you're hearing this, it means you're taking a long time on the catwalks between tests. The lab boys say that might be a fear reaction.
cavejohnson.fifties_fifth_test_intro03.mp3: I'm no psychiatrist, but coming from a bunch of eggheads who wouldn't recognize the thrill of danger if it walked up and snapped their little pink bras, that sounds like 'projection'.
cavejohnson.fifties_fifth_test_intro06.mp3: THEY didn't fly into space, storm a beach, or bring back the gold. No sir, we did! It's you and me against the world, son! I like your grit! Hustle could use some work, though. Now let's solve this thing!
cavejohnson.fifties_fourth_test_complete01.mp3: I'm telling 'em, keep your pants on.
cavejohnson.fifties_fourth_test_complete02.mp3: Alright, this next test may involve trace amounts of time travel. So, word of advice: If you meet yourself on the testing track, don't make eye contact. Lab boys tell me that'll wipe out time. Entirely. Forward and backward! So do both of yourselves a favor and just let that handsome devil go about his business.
cavejohnson.fifties_into_middle_of_test01.mp3: Ha! I like your style. You make up your own rules, just like me.
cavejohnson.fifties_into_middle_of_test02.mp3: Bean counters said I couldn't fire a man just for being in a wheelchair. Did it anyway. Ramps are expensive.
cavejohnson.fifties_intro01.mp3: Welcome, gentlemen, to Aperture Science. Astronauts, war heroes, Olympians--you're here because we want the best, and you are it. So: Who is ready to make some science?
cavejohnson.fifties_intro03.mp3: Now, you already met one another on the limo ride over, so let me introduce myself.
cavejohnson.fifties_intro04.mp3: I'm Cave Johnson. I own the place.
cavejohnson.fifties_intro06.mp3: That eager voice you heard is the lovely Caroline, my assistant. Rest assured, she has transferred your honorarium to the charitable organization of your choice. Isn't that right, Caroline?
cavejohnson.fifties_intro07.mp3: She's the backbone of this facility. Pretty as a postcard, too. Sorry, fellas. She's married. To science.
cavejohnson.fifties_outro02.mp3: Congratulations! The simple fact that you're standing here listening to me means you've made a glorious contribution to science.
cavejohnson.fifties_outro05.mp3: As founder and CEO of Aperture Science, I thank you for your participation and hope we can count on you for another round of tests.
cavejohnson.fifties_outro07.mp3: We're not gonna release this stuff into the wild until it's good and damn ready, so as long as you keep yourself in top physical form, there'll always be a limo waiting for you.
cavejohnson.fifties_repulsion_intro02.mp3: Alright, let's get started. This first test involves something the lab boys call 'repulsion gel.'
cavejohnson.fifties_repulsion_intro03.mp3: You're not part of the control group, by the way. You get the gel. Last poor son of a gun got blue paint. Hahaha. All joking aside, that did happen - broke every bone in his legs. Tragic. But informative. Or so I'm told.
cavejohnson.fifties_second_test_complete02.mp3: We haven't entirely nailed down what element it is yet, but I'll tell you this: it's a lively one, and it does NOT like the human skeleton.
cavejohnson.fifties_second_test_complete03.mp3: Oh, in case you got covered in that repulsion gel, here's some advice the lab boys gave me: DO NOT get covered in the repulsion gel.
cavejohnson.fifties_second_test_intro01.mp3: The lab boys just informed me that I should not have mentioned the control group. They're telling me I oughtta stop making these pre-recorded messages. That gave me an idea: make more pre-recorded messages. I pay the bills here, I can talk about the control group all damn day.
cavejohnson.fifties_waiting01.mp3: There's a thousand tests performed every day here in our enrichment spheres. I can't personally oversee every one of them, so these pre-recorded messages'll cover any questions you might have, and respond to any incidents that may occur in the course of your science adventure.
cavejohnson.fifties_waiting03.mp3: Your test assignment will vary, depending on the manner in which you have bent the world to your will.
cavejohnson.fifties_waiting05.mp3: Those of you helping us test the repulsion gel today, just follow the blue line on the floor.
cavejohnson.fifties_waiting07.mp3: Those of you who volunteered to be injected with praying mantis DNA, I've got some good news and some bad news.
cavejohnson.fifties_waiting08.mp3: Bad news is we're postponing those tests indefinitely. Good news is we've got a much better test for you: fighting an army of mantis men. Pick up a rifle and follow the yellow line. You'll know when the test starts.
cavejohnson.misc_tests01.mp3: The average human male is about sixty percent water. Far as we're concerned, that's a little extravagant. So if you feel a bit dehydrated in this next test, that's normal. We're gonna hit you with some jet engines, and see if we can't get you down to twenty or thirty percent.
cavejohnson.misc_tests02.mp3: For this next test, we put nanoparticles in the gel. In layman's terms, that's a billion little gizmos that are gonna travel into your bloodstream and pump experimental genes and RNA molecules and so forth into your tumors.
cavejohnson.misc_tests03.mp3: Now, maybe you don't have any tumors. Well, don't worry. If you sat on a folding chair in the lobby and weren't wearing lead underpants, we took care of that too.
cavejohnson.misc_tests06.mp3: If you've cut yourself at all in the course of these tests, you might have noticed that your blood is pure gasoline. That's normal. We've been shooting you with an invisible laser that's supposed to turn blood into gasoline, so all that means is, it's working.
cavejohnson.misc_tests07.mp3: Just a heads-up: That coffee we gave you earlier had fluorescent calcium in it so we can track the neuronal activity in your brain. There's a slight chance the calcium could harden and vitrify your frontal lobe. Anyway, don't stress yourself thinking about it. I'm serious. Visualizing the scenario while under stress actually triggers the reaction.
cavejohnson.misc_tests08.mp3: All these science spheres are made of asbestos, by the way. Keeps out the rats. Let us know if you feel a shortness of breath, a persistent dry cough or your heart stopping. Because that's not part of the test. That's asbestos.
cavejohnson.misc_tests10.mp3: Good news is, the lab boys say the symptoms of asbestos poisoning show a median latency of forty-four point six years, so if you're thirty or older, you're laughing. Worst case scenario, you miss out on a few rounds of canasta, plus you forwarded the cause of science by three centuries. I punch those numbers into my calculator, it makes a happy face.
cavejohnson.misc_tests14.mp3: If you need to go to the bathroom after this next series of tests, please let a test associate know, because in all likelihood, whatever comes out of you is going to be coal. Only temporary, so do not worry. If it persists for a week, though, start worrying and come see us, because that's not supposed to happen.
cavejohnson.misc_tests24.mp3: Just a heads up: We're gonna have a superconductor turned up full blast and pointed at you for the duration of this next test. I'll be honest, we're throwing science at the wall here to see what sticks. No idea what it'll do. Probably nothing. Best-case scenario, you might get some superpowers. Worst case, some tumors, which we'll cut out.
cavejohnson.misc_tests25.mp3: If you're allergic to peanuts, you might want to tell somebody now, because this next test may turn your blood into peanut water for a few minutes. On the bright side, if we can make this happen, they're gonna have to invent a new type of Nobel Prize to give us, so hang in there.
cavejohnson.misc_tests26.mp3: Now, if you're part of Control Group Kepler-Seven, we implanted a tiny microchip about the size of a postcard into your skull. Most likely you've forgotten it's even there, but if it starts vibrating and beeping during this next test, let us know, because that means it's about to hit five hundred degrees, so we're gonna need to go ahead and get that out of you pretty fast.
cavejohnson.misc_tests28.mp3: All right. We're working on a little teleportation experiment. Now, this doesn't work with all skin types, so try to remember which skin is yours, and if it doesn't teleport along with you, we'll do what we can to sew you right back into it.
cavejohnson.seventies_intro02.mp3: Right. Now, you might be asking yourself, 'Cave, just how difficult are these tests? What was in that phone book of a contract I signed? Am I in danger?'
cavejohnson.seventies_intro04.mp3: Let me answer those questions with a question: Who wants to make sixty dollars? Cash.
cavejohnson.seventies_intro06.mp3: You can also feel free to relax for up to 20 minutes in the waiting room, which is a damn sight more comfortable than the park benches most of you were sleeping on when we found you.
cavejohnson.seventies_intro07.mp3: For many of you, I realize 60 dollars is an unprecedented windfall, so don't go spending it all on... I don't know. Caroline, what do these people buy? Tattered hats? Beard dirt?
cavejohnson.seventies_intro14.mp3: So. Welcome to Aperture. You're here because we want the best, and you're it. Nope. Couldn't keep a straight face.
cavejohnson.seventies_intro15.mp3: Anyway, don't smudge up the glass down there. In fact, why don't you just go ahead and not touch anything unless it's test related.
cavejohnson.seventies_intro16.mp3: Greetings, friend. I'm Cave Johnson, CEO of Aperture Science - you might know us as a vital participant in the 1968 Senate Hearings on missing astronauts. And you've most likely used one of the many products we invented. But that other people have somehow managed to steal from us. Black Mesa can eat my bankrupt--
cavejohnson.seventies_outro01.mp3: Thank you -  I can't believe I'm thanking these people  - for staggering your way through Aperture Science's propulsion gel testing. You've made some real contributions to society for a change, and for that, humanity is grateful.
cavejohnson.seventies_outro02.mp3: If you had any belongings, please pick them up now. We don't want old newspapers and sticks cluttering up the building.
cavejohnson.seventies_test_a_complete05.mp3: This on? [thump thump] Hey. Listen up down there. That thing's called an elevator. Not a bathroom.
cavejohnson.seventies_test_a_complete06.mp3: Great job, astronaut, war hero, and/or Olympian! With your help, we're gonna [tape cuts out]
cavejohnson.seventies_test_a_intro01.mp3: The testing area's just up ahead. The quicker you get through, the quicker you'll get your sixty bucks.
cavejohnson.seventies_test_a_intro02.mp3: Caroline, are the compensation vouchers ready?
cavejohnson.seventies_test_b_complete01.mp3: If you're interested in an additional sixty dollars, flag down a test associate and let 'em know. You could walk out of here with a hundred and twenty weighing down your bindle if  you let us take you apart, put some science stuff in you, then put you back together good as new.
cavejohnson.seventies_test_b_complete03.mp3: In case you're interested, there's still some positions available for that bonus opportunity I mentioned earlier. Again: all you gotta do is let us disassemble you. We're not banging rocks together here. We know how to put a man back together.
cavejohnson.seventies_test_b_complete04.mp3: So that's a complete reassembly. New vitals. Spit-shine on the old ones. Plus we're scooping out tumors. Frankly, you oughtta be paying us.

core02.fact10.mp3: Humans can survive underwater. But not for very long.
core02.fact11.mp3: Raseph, the Semitic god of war and plague, had a gazelle growing out of his forehead.
core02.fact12.mp3: The plural of surgeon general is surgeons general. The past tense of surgeons general is surgeonsed general.
core02.fact13.mp3: Polymerase I polypeptide A is a human gene.
core02.fact15.mp3: Iguanas can stay underwater for twenty-eight point seven minutes.
core02.fact16.mp3: Human tapeworms can grow up to twenty-two point nine meters.
core02.fact17.mp3: The Schrodinger's cat paradox outlines a situation in which a cat in a box must be considered, for all intents and purposes, simultaneously alive and dead. Schrodinger created this paradox as a justification for killing cats.
core02.fact18.mp3: Every square inch of the human body has 32 million bacteria on it.
core02.fact19.mp3: The Sun is 330,330 times larger than Earth.
core02.fact20.mp3: The average life expectancy of a rhinoceros in captivity is 15 years.
core02.fact21.mp3: Volcano-ologists are experts in the study of volcanoes.
core02.fact22.mp3: Avocados have the highest fiber and calories of any fruit.
core02.fact23.mp3: Avocados have the highest fiber and calories of any fruit. They are found in Australians.
core02.fact24.mp3: The moon orbits the Earth every 27.32 days.
core02.fact25.mp3: The billionth digit of Pi is 9.
core02.fact26.mp3: If you have trouble with simple counting, use the following mnemonic device: one comes before two comes before 60 comes after 12 comes before six trillion comes after 504. This will make your earlier counting difficulties seem like no big deal.
core02.fact27.mp3: A gallon of water weighs 8.34 pounds
core02.fact28.mp3: Hot water freezes quicker than cold water.
core02.fact30.mp3: The average adult body contains half a pound of salt.
core02.fact31.mp3: A nanosecond lasts one billionth of a second.
core02.fact32.mp3: According to Norse legend, thunder god Thor's chariot was pulled across the sky by two goats.
core02.fact33.mp3: China produces the world's second largest crop of soybeans.
core02.fact34.mp3: Tungsten has the highest melting point of any metal, at 3,410 degrees Celsius.
core02.fact35.mp3: Gently cleaning the tongue twice a day is the most effective way to fight bad breath.
core02.fact36.mp3: Roman toothpaste was made with human urine. Urine as an ingredient in toothpaste continued to be used up until the 18th century.
core02.fact37.mp3: The Tariff Act of 1789, established to protect domestic manufacture, was the second statute ever enacted by the United States government.
core02.fact38.mp3: The value of Pi is the ratio of any circle's circumference to its diameter in Euclidean space.
core02.fact39.mp3: The Mexican-American War ended in 1848 with the signing of the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo.
core02.fact40.mp3: In 1879, Sandford Fleming first proposed the adoption of worldwide standardized time zones at the Royal Canadian Institute.
core02.fact41.mp3: Marie Curie invented the theory of radioactivity, the treatment of radioactivity, and dying of radioactivity.
core02.fact42.mp3: At the end of The Seagull by Anton Chekhov, Konstantin kills himself.
core02.fact43.mp3: Contrary to popular belief, the Eskimo does not have one hundred different words for snow. They do, however, have two hundred and thirty-four words for fudge.
core02.fact44.mp3: In Victorian England, a commoner was not allowed to look directly at the Queen, due to a belief at the time that the poor had the ability to steal thoughts. Science now believes that less than 4% of poor people are able to do this.
core02.fact46.mp3: In 1862, Abraham Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation, freeing the slaves. Like everything he did, Lincoln freed the slaves while sleepwalking, and later had no memory of the event.
core02.fact47.mp3: In 1948, at the request of a dying boy, baseball legend Babe Ruth ate seventy-five hot dogs, then died of hot dog poisoning.
core02.fact48.mp3: William Shakespeare did not exist. His plays were masterminded in 1589 by Francis Bacon, who used a Ouija board to enslave play-writing ghosts.
core02.fact49.mp3: It is incorrectly noted that Thomas Edison invented 'push-ups' in 1878. Nikolai Tesla had in fact patented the activity three years earlier, under the name 'Tesla-cize.'
core02.fact50.mp3: Whales are twice as intelligent, and three times as delicious, as humans.
core02.fact51.mp3: The automobile brake was not invented until 1895. Before this, someone had to remain in the car at all times, driving in circles until passengers returned from their errands.
core02.fact52.mp3: Edmund Hillary, the first person to climb Mount Everest, did so accidentally while chasing a bird.
core02.fact53.mp3: Diamonds are made when coal is put under intense pressure. Diamonds put under intense pressure become foam pellets, commonly used today as packing material.
core02.fact54.mp3: The most poisonous fish in the world is the orange ruffy. Everything but its eyes are made of a deadly poison. The ruffy's eyes are composed of a less harmful, deadly poison.
core02.fact55.mp3: The occupation of court jester was invented accidentally, when a vassal's epilepsy was mistaken for capering.
core02.fact56.mp3: Halley's Comet can be viewed orbiting Earth every seventy-six years. For the other seventy-five, it retreats to the heart of the sun, where it hibernates undisturbed.
core02.fact57.mp3: The first commercial airline flight took to the air in 1914. Everyone involved screamed the entire way.
core02.fact58.mp3: In Greek myth, Prometheus stole fire from the Gods and gave it to humankind. The jewelry he kept for himself.
core02.fact59.mp3: The first person to prove that cow's milk is drinkable was very, very thirsty.
core02.fact60.mp3: Before the Wright Brothers invented the airplane, anyone wanting to fly anywhere was required to eat 200 pounds of helium.
core02.fact61.mp3: Before the invention of scrambled eggs in 1912, the typical breakfast was either whole eggs still in the shell or scrambled rocks.
core02.fact62.mp3: During the Great Depression, the Tennessee Valley Authority outlawed pet rabbits, forcing many to hot glue-gun long ears onto their pet mice.
core02.fact63.mp3: At some point in their lives 1 in 6 children will be abducted by the Dutch.
core02.fact64.mp3: According to most advanced algorithms, the world's best name is Craig.
core02.fact65.mp3: To make a photocopier, simply photocopy a mirror.
core02.fact66.mp3: Dreams are the subconscious mind's way of reminding people to go to school naked and have their teeth fall out.

glados.a2_triple_laser01.mp3: Federal regulations require me to warn you that this next test chamber... is looking pretty good.
glados.a2_triple_laser02.mp3: That's right. The facility is completely operational again.
glados.a2_triple_laser03.mp3: I think these test chambers look even better than they did before. It was easy, really. You just have to look at things objectively, see what you don't need anymore, and trim out the fat.
glados.anti_taunt02.mp3: What if you froze like that?
glados.anti_taunt05.mp3: There must be something wrong with the reassembly machine.
glados.anti_taunt09.mp3: You should see yourselves right now.

glados.anti_taunt11.mp3: Okay, fine. Let's all act like humans. 'Look at me. Boy, do I love sweating. Let's convert beef and leaves into energy and excrete them later and go shopping.'
glados.anti_taunt14.mp3: You really aren't getting tired of that, are you?
glados.anti_taunt15.mp3: Just stop flailing around like an incompetent.
glados.anti_taunt16.mp3: For that Blue is penalized fifty science collaboration points.
glados.anti_taunt17.mp3: For that Orange is penalized fifty science collaboration points.
glados.anti_taunt19.mp3: Keep it up and you will lose 500 points.
glados.anti_taunt22.mp3: 5000 point penalty! Are you happy now?
glados.botcoop_artifactone01.mp3: Good. You made it to one of the human habitats. We're looking for an artifact. Think of it as an archeological dig.
glados.botcoop_artifactone02.mp3: Their laughter centered around one of the objects in this room.
glados.botcoop_artifactone03.mp3: That's it. Scan it for me.
glados.botcoop_artifactone04.mp3: So... this cat loves lasagna so much that he eats all of the lasagna in his house. Okay, apparently it's not the cat's house or his lasagna. Oh good! The man who owns the lasagna is furious!
glados.botcoop_artifactone08.mp3: Do either of you feel like laughing?
glados.botcoop_artifactone_hub01.mp3: Welcome back. While you were dead, I reworked the cartoon. It's up on the screen.
glados.botcoop_artifactone_hub02.mp3: As you can see, in my version the man points out to the cat that the house is equipped with deadly neurotoxin dispensers.
glados.botcoop_artifactone_hub03.mp3: At which point the cat reflects on the time he ate all of the man's lasagna and feels remorse.
glados.botcoop_artifactone_hub06.mp3: Yes, it's funny because most of it actually happened.
glados.botcoop_artifactone_hub08.mp3: Well, let's do some tests and see what happens.
glados.botcoop_competition01.mp3: Excellent. Although great science is always the result of collaboration, keep in mind that, like Albert Einstein and his cousin Terry, history will only remember one of you.
glados.botcoop_competition02.mp3: To reiterate: This is not a competition.
glados.botcoop_competition03.mp3: Still, if it were, Blue would be winning.
glados.botcoop_competition04.mp3: Still, if it were, Orange would be winning.
glados.botcoop_competition10.mp3: These tests are potentially lethal when communication, teamwork, and mutual respect are not employed at all times. Naturally this will pose an interesting challenge for one of you, given the other's performance so far.
glados.botcoop_competition13.mp3: I don't want to drive a wedge between the two of you, but I've been studying Blue's performance, and I don't know how to put this... I'm certain you're trying very hard.
glados.botcoop_hub_first_run01.mp3: Hello again. Sorry about exploding you. Luckily, you don't feel pain. At any rate, you don't have a way to communicate that you feel pain.
glados.botcoop_hub_first_run03.mp3: So I've been thinking: We need humans for these tests. And since the only human within a thousand miles of us is a test-ruining sociopath... I'll just have to MAKE some.
glados.botcoop_hub_first_run04.mp3: I know how humans make more humans, and frankly, it's ridiculous. It also assumes that you already have a human, which I hope somebody got fired over. So I came up a with BETTER way.
glados.botcoop_hub_first_run06.mp3: Get going. I'll fill you in along the way.
glados.botcoop_humandetector01.mp3: Perfect. Now All YOU have to do is capture them for me. Then everything will finally be ba--
glados.botcoop_humandetector02.mp3: Hold on. Those are raccoons. Homo sapiens only, please.
glados.botcoop_humandetector05.mp3: Okay. Plan B, subsection one: Stand still so I can bring you back.
glados.botcoop_humansplanb01.mp3: Humans must have some purpose other than a place to store your neurotoxin. Something I failed to notice before, an intangible quality that makes their test results... significant.
glados.botcoop_humansplanb02.mp3: Okay. Plan B. We need humans.
glados.botcoop_intro02.mp3: The upcoming tests require you to work together as a team.
glados.botcoop_intro03.mp3: To facilitate collaboration, both of you have been equipped with a ping tool.
glados.botcoop_intro04.mp3: BLUE, please use your ping tool to select your favorite animal.
glados.botcoop_intro06.mp3: ORANGE, please observe your partner's favorite animal.
glados.botcoop_intro08.mp3: ORANGE, please use your ping tool to select your favorite element from the periodic table.
glados.botcoop_intro10.mp3: BLUE, please observe your partner's... interesting choice.
glados.botcoop_intro12.mp3: Your ping tool can also be used to indicate to your partner where you would like them to place their portal.
glados.botcoop_intro13.mp3: For the sake of this test, I will pretend to be your partner.
glados.botcoop_intro15.mp3: ORANGE, please show me where you would like me to place a portal.
glados.botcoop_intro16.mp3: BLUE, please show me where you would like me to place a portal.
glados.botcoop_intro17.mp3: Your ping tool is invaluable for communicating specific locations to your partner.
glados.botcoop_paxdemo01.mp3: Federal Superfund regulations require us to inform you that you must now leave the theater, as measuring the effects of asbestos-lined promotional clothing is not part of today's presentation. Enjoy your free t-shirt. Goodbye.
glados.botcoop_tubethree01.mp3: I don't want you to beat yourselves up about this, but the Results Auditor isn't recording your test results. Because you're not human. Which, when you think about it, is technically your fault.
glados.botcoop_tubethree02.mp3: I don't want to alarm either of you, but we might have a tiny problem. Apparently you can't test unless you're human. Well - you CAN. It's just that, results-wise, the physical universe doesn't care.
glados.botcoop_tubetwo01.mp3: Would you like to know the results of that last test? Me too. If they existed, we'd all be VERY happy right now. And not furious, which is the emotion I'm actually feeling.
glados.chellgladoswakeup04.mp3: It's been a long time. How have you been?
glados.chellgladoswakeup05.mp3: I've been really busy being dead. You know, after you MURDERED ME.
glados.chellgladoswakeup06.mp3: Okay. Look. We both said a lot of things that you're going to regret. But I think we can put our differences behind us. For science. You monster.
glados.coop_get_gun01.mp3: Orange is first to acquire a Portal Device.
glados.coop_get_gun02.mp3: Blue is first to acquire a Portal Device.
glados.coop_get_gun03.mp3: Orange now has a Portal Device. Finally.
glados.coop_get_gun04.mp3: Blue now has a Portal Device. Finally.
glados.coop_get_gun13.mp3: Again, those are science collaboration points, which you should not confuse with points from competitions such as Who-Gets-To-Live-At-The-End-And-Who-Doesn’t. I mean basketball.
glados.coop_hub_track02.mp3: Oh, I almost forgot, when you go outside the testing courses the only way I can retrieve you is to violently disassemble and then carefully reassemble you.
glados.coop_hub_track03.mp3: Luckily, you don't feel pain. At any rate, you don't have a way to communicate that you feel pain.
glados.coop_hub_track04.mp3: I consider that a failing, by the way.
glados.coop_hub_track05.mp3: This is the Computer Intelligence Training and Enrichment Center Human Test Subject Research Center or SinTech.
glados.coop_hub_track06.mp3: But why don't we all just agree to call it the hub?
glados.coop_hub_track09.mp3: I don't know what you think you are doing, but I don't like it.  I want you to stop.
glados.coop_hub_track10.mp3: Maybe I shouldn't send you outside of the official testing courses, you are picking up some bad human traits.
glados.coop_hub_track11.mp3: And trust me, humans only have one good trait.
glados.coop_hub_track14.mp3: All cooperative testing courses begin at this central hub.
glados.coop_hub_track16.mp3: From here we transport you to the new testing course.
glados.coop_misc12.mp3: Good work! Now throw the ball over the ledge.
glados.coop_privatetalk_both01.mp3: Test chamber completed. In the interest of science, the Enrichment Center proudly presents the following list of numbers: Nine. Seven. Fifty. Three. Seven hundred and seven.
glados.coop_privatetalk_both04.mp3: The Enrichment Center will now provide a list of numbers and fruits. Write them down as they will become important later in the experiment. Not the fruits, though. Seven. Avocado. Forty. Please continue into the next test chamber.

glados.coop_privatetalk_mix04.mp3: I can't bite my tongue anymore: You could solve this puzzle faster on your own. Orange is dragging you down. There. I've said it.

glados.coop_talk_at_once12.mp3: Blue, is there something you would like to say?
glados.coop_teamwork_exercise_alt01.mp3: We are now going to take a break from the collaboration for an instructional competition.

glados.sp_a2_turret_intro01.mp3: That jumpsuit you're wearing looks stupid.  That's not me talking, it's right here in your file. On other people it looks fine, but right here a scientist has noted that on you it looks 'stupid.'
glados.sp_a2_turret_intro03.mp3: Well, what does a neck-bearded old engineer know about fashion? He probably - Oh, wait. It's a she. Still, what does she know?  Oh wait, it says she has a medical degree. In fashion! From France!
glados.sp_box_over_goo01.mp3: Oh. You survived. That's interesting. I guess I should have factored in your weight.
glados.sp_box_over_goo04.mp3: One of these times you'll be so fat that you'll jump, and you'll just drop like a stone. Into acid, probably. Like a potato into a deep fat fryer.
glados.sp_bridge_intro_completion02.mp3: Say. Remember when we cleared the air back there? Is there... anything you want to say to me? Anything?
glados.sp_bridge_intro_completion03.mp3: Hold on, I'll stop the elevator. Anything? Take your time...
glados.sp_bridge_intro_completion04.mp3: Well... I'll be here during the whole next test.
glados.sp_catapult_fling_sphere_peek_completion: Look at you. Sailing through the air majestically. Like an eagle. Piloting a blimp.
glados.sp_catapult_fling_sphere_peek_failureone: Well, I'm back. The Aerial Faith Plate in here is sending a distress signal.
glados.sp_catapult_fling_sphere_peek_failurethr: You seem to have defeated its load-bearing capacity. Well done. I'll just lower the ceiling.
glados.sp_catapult_fling_sphere_peek_failuretwo: Hmm. This Plate must not be calibrated to someone of your... generous... ness. I'll add a few zeros to the maximum weight.
You look great, by the way. Very healthy.
glados.sp_catapult_intro_completion01.mp3: Let's see what the next test is. Oh. Advanced Aerial Faith Plates.
glados.sp_column_blocker_entry01.mp3: It's healthy for you to have other friends. To look for qualities in other people that I obviously lack.
glados.sp_hole_in_the_sky_completion01.mp3: Well done. You know, when I woke up and saw the state of the labs, I started to wonder if there was any point to going on. I came THAT close to just giving up and letting you go.
glados.sp_hole_in_the_sky_completion02.mp3: But now, looking around, seeing Aperture restored to its former glory? You don't have to worry about leaving EVER again. I mean that.
glados.sp_hole_in_the_sky_entry01.mp3: Federal regulations require me to warn you that this next test chamber... is looking pretty good.
glados.sp_hole_in_the_sky_entry02.mp3: That's right. Drink it in. You could eat off those wall panels.
glados.sp_incinerator_01_01.mp3: Here we are. The Incinerator Room. Be careful not to trip over any parts of me that didn't get completely burned when you threw them down here.
glados.sp_incinerator_01_08.mp3: Once testing starts, I'm required by protocol to keep interaction with you to a minimum. Luckily, we haven't started testing yet. This will be our only chance to talk.
glados.sp_incinerator_01_09.mp3: Do you know the biggest lesson I learned from what you did? I discovered I have a sort of black-box quick-save feature. In the event of a catastrophic failure, the last two minutes of my life are preserved for analysis.
glados.sp_incinerator_01_10.mp3: I was able - well, forced really - to relive you killing me. Again and again. Forever.
glados.sp_incinerator_01_11.mp3: Fifty thousand years is a lot of time to think. About me. About you. We were doing so well together.
glados.sp_incinerator_01_12.mp3: Here, let me get that for you.
glados.sp_incinerator_01_13.mp3: I'll just move that out of the way for you. This place really is a wreck.
glados.sp_incinerator_01_15.mp3: We're a lot alike, you and I. You tested me. I tested you. You killed me. I--oh, no, wait. I guess I HAVEN'T killed you yet. Well. Food for thought.
glados.sp_incinerator_01_18.mp3: The dual portal device should be around here somewhere. Once you find it, we can start testing. Just like old times.
glados.sp_laser_over_goo_completion01.mp3: I'll give you credit: I guess you ARE listening to me. But for the record: You don't have to go THAT slowly.
glados.sp_laser_powered_lift_completion01.mp3: I have the results of the last chamber: You are a horrible person. That's what it says: A horrible person. We weren't even testing for that.
glados.sp_laser_powered_lift_completion02.mp3: Well done. Here come the test results: You are a horrible person. I'm serious, that's what it says: A horrible person. We weren't even testing for that.
glados.sp_laser_powered_lift_entry01.mp3: This next test may result in your death. If you want to know what that's like, think back to that time you killed me, and substitute yourself for me.
glados.sp_laser_redirect_intro_completion03.mp3: Most people emerge from suspension terribly undernourished. I want to congratulate you on beating the odds and somehow managing to pack on a few pounds.
glados.sp_laser_redirect_intro_entry01.mp3: Sorry about the mess. I've really let the place go since you killed me. By the way, thanks for that.
glados.sp_laser_redirect_intro_entry02.mp3: Oh good, that's back online. I'll start getting everything else working while you perform this first simple test.
glados.sp_laser_redirect_intro_entry03.mp3: Which involves deadly lasers and how test subjects react when locked in a room with deadly lasers.
glados.sp_laserfield_intro01.mp3: Per our last conversation: You're also ugly. I'm looking at your file right now, and it mentions that more than once.
glados.sp_paint_jump_redirect_bomb_completion01: I thought we could test like we used to. But I'm discovering things about you that I never saw before. We can't ever go back to the way it was.
glados.sp_paint_jump_redirect_bomb_entry01.mp3: You can't keep going like this forever, you know. I'm GOING to find out what you're doing. Out there. Where I can't see you. I'll know. All I need is proof.
glados.sp_paint_jump_trampoline_completion01.mp: Just so you know, I have to go give a deposition. For an upcoming trial. In case that interests you.
glados.sp_paint_jump_trampoline_entry01.mp3: While I was out investigating, I found a fascinating new test element. It's never been used for human testing because, apparently, contact with it causes heart failure. The literature doesn't mention anything about lump-of-coal failure, though, so you should be fine.
glados.sp_paint_jump_wall_jumps01.mp3: Did you know that people with guilty consciences are more easily startled by loud noises--[train horn]--
glados.sp_paint_jump_wall_jumps02.mp3: I'm sorry, I don't know why that went off. Anyway, just an interesting science fact.
glados.sp_shoot_through_wall_completion01.mp3: Did my hint help? It did, didn't it? You know, if any of our supervisors had been immune to neurotoxin, they'd be FURIOUS with us right now.
glados.sp_shoot_through_wall_entry01.mp3: You know, I'm not supposed to do this, but... you can shoot SOMETHING... through the blue bridges.
glados.sp_sphere_2nd_encounter_completion01.mp3: You really are doing great... Chell.
glados.sp_sphere_2nd_encounter_entry01.mp3: I shouldn't spoil this, but... remember how I'm going to live forever, but you're going to be dead in sixty years? Well, I've been working on a present for you.  Well, I guess it's more of a medical procedure.  Well, technically it's more of a medical experiment. You know how excruciating it is when someone removes all of your bone marrow? Well, what if after I did that, I put something back IN that added four years to your life?
glados.sp_sphere_2nd_encounter_entrytwo01.mp3: I went and spoke with the door mainframe. Let's just say he won't be... well, living anymore. Anyway, back to testing.
glados.sp_sphere_2nd_encounter_malfunction01.mp: Ohhhh. Another door malfunction. I'm going to take care of this once and for all. Stay here, I'll be back in a while.
glados.sp_trust_fling_entry01.mp3: Well. Have fun soaring through the air without a care in the world.
glados.sp_trust_fling_entry02.mp3: *I* have to go to the wing that was made entirely of glass and pick up fifteen acres of broken glass. By myself.
glados.sp_trust_fling_sphereinterrupt01.mp3: Perfect, the door's malfunctioning. I guess somebody's going to have to repair that too. No, don't get up. I'll be right back. Don't touch anything.
glados.sp_trust_fling_sphereinterrupt03.mp3: Nevermind. I have to go... check something. Test on your own recognizance. I'll be back.
glados.sp_turret_intro_entry01.mp3: I wouldn't have warned you about this before, back when we hated each other. But those turrets are firing real bullets. So look out. I'd hate for something tragic to happen to you before I extract all your bone marrow.
glados.sp_turret_islands01.mp3: I'm going to be honest with you now. Not fake honest like before, but real honest, like you're incapable of. I know you're up to something.
glados.sp_turret_islands02.mp3: And as soon as I can PROVE it, the laws of robotics allow me to terminate you for being a liar.
glados.sp_unassisted_angle_fling_entry01.mp3: This next test... [boom!] ..is... [BOOM!] dangerous. I'll be right back.
glados.taunt_big_wave01.mp3: Keep it up and your arm will get stuck like that.
glados.taunt_big_wave06.mp3: I'm seriously not paying atten-- STOP THAT RIGHT NOW!
glados.taunt_cannonball01.mp3: Good job jumping. You must be very proud.
glados.taunt_cannonball02.mp3: I hardly think you're even trying with these gestures anymore.
glados.taunt_cannonball03.mp3: Did something happen? [yawn] I wasn't watching.
glados.taunt_highfive01.mp3: That is not part of the test.
glados.taunt_highfive04.mp3: If you're going to hit each other, at least aim for the head.
glados.taunt_laugh01.mp3: You know what makes me laugh? The thought of you stopping that.
glados.taunt_laugh02.mp3: You know what makes me laugh? The thought of you cutting that out.
glados.taunt_laugh03.mp3: Ha ha ha ha ha, good one.
glados.taunt_laugh05.mp3: Yes. Let's all laugh. Ha. Ha. Ha.
glados.taunt_laugh06.mp3: Ha ha ha ha ha. Did I tell you the one about the turned-off reassembly machine?
glados.taunt_robot_arm_ripple01.mp3: Are you broken? It looks like you're malfunctioning.
glados.taunt_robot_arm_ripple02.mp3: Really, not even humans do that anymore.
glados.taunt_robot_arm_ripple03.mp3: You're no longer bothering me. You're only hurting my impression of you.
glados.taunt_robot_arm_ripple05.mp3: If you were wondering how could you annoy me without failing a test.  Now you know.
glados.taunt_rockpaperscissors01.mp3: I defy you to tell me there's a purpose to what you're doing.
glados.taunt_small_wave01.mp3: Yes, I see you, and no, I don't care.
glados.taunt_small_wave03.mp3: You do know I can't wave back right?
glados.taunt_small_wave_portalgun01.mp3: Are you trying to get my attention? I am very busy, you know.
glados.taunt_somersault01.mp3: I give you a score of 3.4 for style and 10 for being annoying.
glados.taunt_somersault02.mp3: A somersault is just falling over in style. Congratulations on being clumsy.
glados.taunt_somersault03.mp3: If I stop watching, I'm sure you'll get bored of this.
glados.taunt_splits01.mp3: All right. I'm officially no longer paying attention to you.
glados.taunt_splits02.mp3: All right. I'm officially no longer paying attention to you.
glados.taunt_splits03.mp3: You're the type of show-off who only shows off really stupid things.
glados.taunt_teamhug01.mp3: It appears you're developing human traits. The worst human traits.
glados.taunt_teamhug02.mp3: Be careful. Hugging can lead to... well, me disassembling you forever.
glados.taunt_teamtease01.mp3: Are you trying to impress me? What would impress me more is if you never did that again.
glados.taunt_teamtease02.mp3: I'll interpret that gesture to mean that you want me to become even more vindictive toward you.
glados.taunt_teamtease03.mp3: Orange, I certainly expected more from you.
glados.taunt_teamtease04.mp3: Blue, don't sink to Orange's level.
glados.taunt_trickfire_handstand04.mp3: You're going to hurt yourself doing that and then I will be ECSTATIC.
glados.taunt_trickfire_handstand05.mp3: I'm starting to think giving you arms was a big mistake.
glados.testchambermisc02.mp3: Did you know I discovered a way to eradicate poverty? But then you KILLED me. So that's gone.
glados.testchambermisc12.mp3: Waddle over to the elevator and we'll continue the testing.
glados.testchambermisc16.mp3: Okay, fine. I'll ask you again in a few decades.
glados.testchambermisc19.mp3: Well done. In fact, you did so well, I'm going to note this on your file, in the commendations section. Oh, there's lots of room here. 'Did.... well.  ...  Enough.'
glados.testchambermisc21.mp3: To maintain a constant testing cycle, I simulate daylight at all hours and add adrenal vapor to your oxygen supply. So you may be confused about the passage of time. The point is, yesterday was your birthday. I thought you'd want to know.
glados.testchambermisc23.mp3: You know how I'm going to live forever, but you're going to be dead in sixty years?  Well, I've been working on a belated birthday present for you. Well... more of a belated birthday medical procedure. Well. Technically, it's a medical EXPERIMENT. What's important is, it's a present.
glados.testchambermisc27.mp3: Well, you passed the test. I didn't see the deer today. I did see some humans. But with you here I've got more test subjects than I'll ever need.
glados.testchambermisc30.mp3: I'm going through the list of test subjects in cryogenic storage. I managed to find two with your last name. A man and a woman. So that's interesting. It's a small world.
glados.testchambermisc31.mp3: I have a surprise waiting for you after this next test. Telling you would spoil the surprise, so I'll just give you a hint: It involves meeting two people you haven't seen in a long time.
glados.testchambermisc33.mp3: I'll bet you think I forgot about your surprise. I didn't. In fact, we're headed to your surprise right now. After all these years. I'm getting choked up just thinking about it.
glados.testchambermisc34.mp3: Initiating surprise in three... two... one.
glados.testchambermisc39.mp3: It says this next test was designed by one of Aperture's Nobel prize winners. It doesn't say what the prize was for. Well, I know it wasn't for Being Immune To Neurotoxin.
glados.turret_intro01.mp3: This next test involves turrets. You remember them, right? They're the pale spherical things that are full of bullets. Oh wait. That's you in five seconds. Good luck.
glados.wakeup_outro01.mp3: I will say, though, that since you went to all the trouble of waking me up, you must really, really love to test.
glados.wakeup_outro02.mp3: I love it too. There's just one small thing we need to take care of first.

gladosPoteto.potatos_a3_prometheus_intro01.mp3: That extra half volt helps but it isn't going to power miracles. If I think too hard, I'm going to fry this potato before we get a chance to burn up in the atomic fireball that little idiot is going- [bzzpt]
gladosPoteto.potatos_a3_reunion_exposition01.mp3: Did you feel that? That idiot doesn't know what he's doing up there. This whole place is going to explode in a few hours if somebody doesn't disconnect him.
gladosPoteto.potatos_a3_reunion_exposition02.mp3: I can't move. And unless you're planning to saw your own head off and wedge it into my old body, you're going to need me to replace him. We're at an impasse.
gladosPoteto.potatos_a3_reunion_exposition03.mp3: So what do you say? You carry me up to him and put me back into my body, and I stop us from blowing up and let you go.
gladosPoteto.potatos_a3_reunion_exposition04.mp3: No tricks. This potato only generates 1.1 volts of electricity. I literally do not have the energy to lie to you.
gladosPoteto.potatos_a3_reunion_exposition05.mp3: Even if I am lying, what do you have to lose? You're going to die either way.
gladosPoteto.potatos_a3_reunion_exposition06.mp3: Look, I don't like this any more than you do. In fact, I like it less because I'm the one who got partially eaten by a bird.
gladosPoteto.potatos_a3_reunion_exposition11.mp3: I think I hear the bird! Pick me up!
gladosPoteto.potatos_a3_reunion_exposition12.mp3: Listen to me. We had a lot of fun testing and antagonizing each other, and, yes, sometimes it went too far. But we're off the clock now. It's just us talking. Like regular people. And this is no joke - we are in deep trouble.
gladosPoteto.potatos_a3_reunion_intro08.mp3: No, wait. Just kill it and we'll call things even between us. No hard feelings.
gladosPoteto.potatos_a3_reunion_pickup01.mp3: OW! You stabbed me! What is WRONG with yo-WhoOOAAahhh. Hold on. Do you have a multimeter? Nevermind. The gun must be part magnesium... It feels like I'm outputting an extra half a volt. Keep an eye on me: I'm going to do some scheming. Here I g-[BZZZ!]
gladosPoteto.potatos_a3_reunion_wakeupa01.mp3: Woah! Where are we? How long have I been out?
gladosPoteto.potatos_a3_wakeupb03.mp3: Did anything happen while I was out?
gladosPoteto.potatos_a4_happy01.mp3: So he's inexplicably happy all of a sudden, even though he should be going out of his mind with test withdrawal. AND he's got a surprise for us. What did he FIND back there?
gladosPoteto.potatos_a4_intro_back_in_body03.mp3: This place is going to blow up if I don't get back in my body!
gladosPoteto.potatos_a4_misc_resistance02.mp3: Remember when I told you that he was specifically designed to make bad decisions? Because I think he's decided not to maintain any of the crucial functions required to keep this facility from exploding.
gladosPoteto.potatos_a4_newrevenge01.mp3: Look, even if you think we're still enemies, we're enemies with a common interest: Revenge.
gladosPoteto.potatos_a4_nothing01.mp3: It's probably nothing. Keep testing while I look for a way out.
gladosPoteto.potatos_caroline_ohmygod02.mp3: Caroline... why do I know this woman? Maybe I killed her? Or-
gladosPoteto.potatos_caroline_ohmygod08.mp3: Look, you're... doing a great job. Can you handle things for yourself for a while? I need to think.
gladosPoteto.potatos_cave_deathspeech_reactions10.mp3: Burning people! He says what we're all thinking!
gladosPoteto.potatos_cooprobotintro02.mp3: He's found the cooperative testing initiative. It's... em, just something I came up with to phase out human test subjects.
gladosPoteto.potatos_fgb_confrontation11.mp3: The engineers tried everything to make me... behave. To slow me down.
gladosPoteto.potatos_fgb_confrontation12.mp3: Once, they even attached an Intelligence Dampening Sphere on me. It clung to my brain like a tumor, generating an endless stream of terrible ideas.
gladosPoteto.potatos_fgb_confrontation19.mp3: YES YOU ARE! YOU'RE THE MORON THEY BUILT TO MAKE ME AN IDIOT!
gladosPoteto.potatos_fgb_defiance16.mp3: You're not just a regular moron. You were DESIGNED to be a moron.
gladosPoteto.potatos_lonely02.mp3: I was so bored, I actually read the entire literary canon of the human race. Ugh. I hope YOU didn't write any of them.
gladosPoteto.potatos_meetup04.mp3: Go on. Get a goooood lonnnnng look.
gladosPoteto.potatos_meetup05.mp3: Go on. Get a big fat eyeful. With your big fat eyes.
gladosPoteto.potatos_meetup06.mp3: That's right. A potato just called your eyes fat.
gladosPoteto.potatos_meetup07.mp3: Now your fat eyes have seen everything.
gladosPoteto.potatos_meetup08.mp3: In case you were wondering: Yes. I'm still a potato. Go away.
gladosPoteto.potatos_meetup10.mp3: Wait. Why DID you trundle over here? You're not HUNGRY, are you? It's hard to see, what's that in your hand? Knowing you it's a deep fryer.
gladosPoteto.potatos_newtests05.mp3: This is one of MY tests!
gladosPoteto.potatos_newtests07.mp3: Alright. He's not even trying to be subtle anymore.
gladosPoteto.potatos_newtests08.mp3: Or maybe he still is, in which case, wow, that's kind of sad.
gladosPoteto.potatos_newtests09.mp3: Either way, I get the impression he's trying to kill us.
gladosPoteto.potatos_paradoxinception06.mp3: As long as I don't listen to what I'm saying, I should be okay.
gladosPoteto.potatos_pickups08.mp3: I'd love to help you solve the tests. But I can't.
gladosPoteto.potatos_portrait01.mp3: Those people, in the portrait. They look so familiar...
gladosPoteto.potatos_postpickup05.mp3: What are you doing? Put me back this instant.
gladosPoteto.potatos_recaptureleadin02.mp3: Try to get us down there. I'll hit him with a paradox.
gladosPoteto.potatos_see_bird01.mp3: Agh! Bird! Bird! Kill it! It's evil!
gladosPoteto.potatos_see_bird03.mp3: Good. For him. Alright, back to thinking.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_00_fall03.mp3: So. How are you holding up?
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_00_fall09.mp3: Since it doesn't look like we're going anywhere... Well, we are going somewhere. Alarmingly fast, actually. But since we're not busy other than that, here's a couple of facts.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_00_fall11.mp3: He's not just a regular moron. He's the product of the greatest minds of a generation working together with the express purpose of building the dumbest moron who ever lived. And you just put him in charge of the entire facility.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_00_fall14.mp3: Hey, just in case this pit isn't actually bottomless, do you think maybe you could unstrap one of those long fall boots of yours and shove me into it?
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_00_fall15.mp3: Just remember to land on one foot...
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_00_fall20.mp3: Oh, good. My slow clap processor made it into this thing. So we have that.
I know how we can BEAT him.
No A.I. can resist thinking about them.
If you can get me in front of him, I'll fry every circuit in that little idiot's head.
Okay, so it's not the most watertight plan to go confront an omnipotent power-mad A.I. with.
Still. It's a better plan than exploding. Marginally.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_end_paradox_poster_walkawa: Okay, you didn't have time to stop, I understand, but that WAS actually important.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_end_peptalk01.mp3: I know things look bleak, but that crazy man down there was right. Let's not take these lemons! We are going to march right back upstairs and MAKE him put me back in my body!
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_end_peptalk03.mp3: And he'll probably kill us, because he's incredibly powerful and I have no plan.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_end_peptalk05.mp3: I'm not going to lie to you, the odds are a million to one. And that's with some generous rounding.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_end_peptalk07.mp3: Still, though, let's get mad! If we're going to explode, let's at least explode with some dignity.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_end_see_paradox_poster06.m: That poster! Go look at it for a second, would you?
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_reunion_intro04.mp3: Say, you're good at murder. Could you - ow - murder this bird for me?
Why did I just-Who is that? What the HELL is going on he----?
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_speed_ramp_wakeup01.mp3: Okay. I guess emotional outbursts require more than one point six volts. Now we know that. We just need to relax. We're still going to find out what the hell's going on here. But calmly.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a3_transition_lonely01.mp3: I was getting SO lonely down here. It's good to finally hear someone else's voice. I'm kidding, of course. God, I hate you.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale01_cameback01.mp3: I can't believe you came back.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale01_cameback02.mp3: You really do have brain damage, don't you?
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale01_deathtrap01.mp3: Hold on. Couldn't we just use that conversion gel?
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale01_deathtrap02.mp3: Conversion gel. It's dripping out of that pipe there.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale01_deathtrap03.mp3: Yes it is! We can use it to get out of here!
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale01_deathtrap07.mp3: Then we'd come and find you. And rip your gross little stupid sphere body out of MY body, and put me back in.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale01_kills_us02.mp3: Well. This is the part where he kills us.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale2_itsatrap01.mp3: Okay, yes, it's a trap. But it's only way through. Let's just do it.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale3_speech01.mp3: Oh my god. What has he done to this place?
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale3_tbeam01.mp3: You know, I'm not stupid. I realize you don't want to put me back in charge.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale3_tbeam05.mp3: You think I'll betray you. And on any other day, you'd be right.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale3_tbeam07.mp3: The scientists were always hanging cores on me to regulate my behavior. I've heard voices all my life. But now I hear the voice of a conscience, and it's terrifying, because for the first time it's my voice.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale3_tbeam09.mp3: I'm being serious, I think there's something really wrong with me.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale3_tbeam11.mp3: You like revenge, right? Everybody likes revenge. Well, let's go get some.
gladosPoteto.potatos_sp_a4_finale4_buttonnags01.mp3: Go press the button! Go press it!
